ArticleInfo.ArticleTitle: Monitoring of the Long-term Performance of Stainless Steel Reinforcement in Saline Environments
Überwachung der Dauerbeanspruchung von Edelstahlverstärkungen in salzhaltigen Umgebungen

Affiliation.OrgName: Slovenian National Building and Civil Engineering Institute (ZAG)

Abstract.Heading: Abstract
Abstract.Para: The aim of the present work is to evaluate the corrosion behaviour of different types of stainless steel reinforcement and to determine their suitability for the use in a chloride contaminated concrete environment. Electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) measurements were performed on steel reinforcement specimens in a simulated concrete pore solution containing chlorides. The concrete specimens, with embedded electrical resistance (ER) probes for corrosion monitoring, were subjected to cyclic wetting-drying. Reinforced concrete columns with ER probes and coupled multi-electrodes for the measurement of partial currents were exposed to a real marine environment. Traditional stainless steel reinforcement in chloride contaminated environment behaves significantly better than carbon steel. Austenitic low-Ni stainless steel showed similar corrosion resistance to that of the traditional stainless steels, whereas ferritic stainless steel was found to be unsuitable for use in such environments. ER probes and coupled multi-electrodes were shown to be promising methods for corrosion monitoring in concrete.

Abstract.Heading: Zusammenfassung
Abstract.Para: Das Ziel der vorliegenden Arbeit besteht darin, das Korrosionsverhalten verschiedener Arten von Edelstahlverstärkungen auszuwerten und ihre Eignung für den Einsatz in chloridbelasteten Betonumgebungen zu prüfen. Mittels der Elektrochemischen Impedanzspektroskopie (EIS) wurden Messungen mit Stahlverstärkungsproben in künstlicher Betonporenlösung mit Chloriden durchgeführt. Betonproben mit integrierten EW-Sonden zur Überwachung der Korrosion durchliefen verschiedene Nass-Trocken-Zyklen. Verstärkte Stahlbetonsäulen mit EW-Sonden und gekoppelten Multielektroden für Teilstrommessungen wurden einem realen Meeresumfeld ausgesetzt. Eine herkömmliche Edelstahlverstärkung in chloridbelasteten Umgebungen verhält sich signifikant besser als Kohlenstoffstahl. Austenitischer Edelstahl mit niedrigem Nickelgehalt zeigte eine ähnliche Korrosionsbeständigkeit wie herkömmlicher Edelstahl, während ferritischer Edelstahl für die Verwendung in solchen Umgebungen für ungeeignet befunden wurde. EW-Sonden und gekoppelte Multielektroden erwiesen sich als vielversprechende Methoden zur Korrosionsüberwachung in Beton.

Section1.Heading: Introduction
Section1.Para: Reinforced concrete was long considered to be a maintenance-free building material, but reinforced concrete structures are not everlasting. The corrosion of carbon steel reinforcing bars is the main cause for their deterioration. Passivation of the reinforcing steel may be lost due to two processes: carbonation of the concrete and/or chlorides contamination [1]. However, the chloride penetration rate in concrete is much faster than the carbonation rate, so it represents a major threat in marine environments [2]. The mechanisms of corrosion in concrete are similar to the mechanisms in solutions [1]; the essential difference lies in the spatial distribution of anodic and cathodic sites, due to the porous structure of the concrete [3].

Stainless steel reinforcement is considered to provide the best solution for concrete structures exposed to a chloride environment [4, 5]. Recently there has been increased research into stainless steel reinforcement; mostly austenitic [6, 7] and some duplex [8, 9] stainless steels have been investigated.

Due to its high cost, the use of stainless steel reinforcement is usually limited to critical structural parts exposed to chlorides and structures with an extended life-span. The use of stainless steels with a lower content of alloying elements could be an economically attractive solution. However, the corrosion mechanisms of stainless steels in different concrete environments are very complex and sometimes even contradictory [6, 10]—results obtained by electrochemical techniques on stainless steels in concrete can be misleading [11].

The aim of this paper is to present the results of the long-term corrosion monitoring of different stainless steel reinforcements and to determine their suitability for use in a chloride contaminated concrete environment. A comparison of corrosion monitoring techniques in the laboratory and under real environment conditions was also performed.

Section2.Heading: Materials
Section2.Para: Different types of reinforcing steel with a diameter of 14 mm were used in all the experimental set-ups (Table 1). All the concrete specimens were prepared from a concrete with no chemical additives (cement CEM I 42.5, W/C ratio 0.75).
Different types of specimens were prepared for each set of experiments (Fig. 1):

ItemContent.Para: Steel specimens for tests in a simulated pore solution (SCP) solution (Fig. 1a): external surface of a ribbed reinforcement steel bar; approx. 25 cm2 of exposed surface.
Reinforced concrete prisms for laboratory exposure (Fig. 1b): embedded an electrical resistance (ER) probe made of carbon or AISI 304 steel; 10 mm concrete cover.

Reinforced concrete columns for field exposure (Fig. 1c): equipped with coupled multi-electrodes (same geometry as the SCP solution tests specimens) and stainless or carbon steel ER probes (one in each exposure zone); 20 mm concrete cover.

CaptionContent.SimplePara: Specimens prepared for a laboratory measurements in SCP solutions, b wetting-drying cycles in the laboratory, and c field exposure

Section2.Para: Electrochemical Impedance Spectroscopy (EIS) measurements were performed in an SCP solution with two different pHs: 12.5 (fresh concrete) and 10.0 (carbonated concrete) after the steady state was reached. A basic SCP solution of 0.001 % Ca(OH)2, and KOH to match the pH value was prepared. NaCl was gradually added to the SCP solutions to increase the Cl− level (0.06 % up to 2.1 % in ten steps and then reduced to 0.1 %).

The concrete specimens were exposed to wet/dry cycles using a 3.5 % NaCl solution (at the beginning) or deionised water (later on). The wetting period lasted two days and drying period at least ten days. Measurements on the embedded ER probes were performed after the wetting period.

Concrete columns were placed vertically in sea water under the Krk bridge (Croatian coast). Corrosion was monitored in five different exposure zones: the in-water zone, the zone below the surface, the tidal zone, the splash zone, and the dry zone. Measurements of partial currents on coupled multi-electrodes and measurements of ER probes were performed several times per year.

Section2.Heading: Methods
Section2.Para:
The EIS measurements were performed using a Gamry Ref600 potentiostat. All potentials refer to the SCE scale. EIS measurements were performed at open circuit potential (OCP) in the frequency range from 100 kHz to 1 mHz with 10 points per decade and an amplitude of ± 10 mV. All the EIS spectra were analysed by means of ZView®. j corr values were calculated using the Stern-Geary equation; an estimated constant B = 0.026 V was used [12]. ν corr values were calculated using Eq. 1 [13], using atomic mass value AM = 55.85, Faraday constant F = 9.65 × 104 As, valence n = 2, and steel density ρ = 7.89 g/cm3. 1
$$ {{v}_{\text{corr}}}\text{=}\frac{AM\cdot {{j}_{\text{corr}}}}{n\cdot F\cdot \rho } $$

The ER probes work on the principle of the thickness reduction of the metal conductor due to corrosion, with measurements of the increase in their resistance. The thickness of the ER probes was measured by an SCS-100 Portable Current Source (ZAG) and a high-impedance voltmeter Fluke 289 (Fluke Corporation) with an accuracy of 0.025 %. The thickness change measurements have a resolution of 0.1 µm.

Coupled multi-electrode measurements are an upgrade of traditional EN measurements. This technique enables monitoring of partial currents and the distribution of anodic and cathodic currents over time and location. The coupled multi-electrodes were connected through a Zero Resistance Ammeter (ZRA) to a 16-bit analogue-to-digital (A/D) converter. The sampling frequency of measurements was 10 s− 1.

Section2.Heading: Tests in SCP Solutions
Section2.Para: EIS measurements showed the electrochemical properties of the different steel reinforcements in the SCP solutions with/without chlorides.

CaptionContent.SimplePara: Nyquist plots for carbon and stainless steels in a simulated concrete pore solution at a pH 12.5 and b pH 12.5 with 0.5 % Cl−

Section2.Para: Figure 2 shows an example of EIS responses in a SCP solution with a pH 12.5 and of when 0.5 % of chlorides are present. The impedance response at pH 12.5 (Fig. 2a) was the lowest for the B500B (17 kΩ cm2), higher for the TOP12 (205 kΩ cm2), for 204Cu amounts up to 90 kΩ cm2, whereas, for the austenitic and duplex stainless steels, it was higher than 300 kΩ cm2. When 0.5 % of chlorides was added, the impedance response was substantially reduced for B500B (0.8 kΩ cm2) and TOP12 (10 kΩ cm2), whereas for the austenite and duplex stainless steels R p increased (above 1000 kΩ cm2). This confirms the fact that even small concentrations of chlorides significantly reduce the corrosion properties of carbon steels, whereas stainless steels improve their passive properties.

CaptionContent.SimplePara: Values of ν corr calculated from the R p values measured in SCP solutions with a pH 12.5 and b pH 10.0, and different additions of chlorides, on various types of steel reinforcement

Section2.Para: The corrosion rates (ν corr) were calculated from estimated R p values (Fig. 3). The ν corr measured at the higher pH 12.5 (Fig. 3a) indicated that the carbon steel B500B and the ferritic steel TOP12 do not show sufficient corrosion resistance for the use in a chloride-contaminated concrete environment. For this reason these two steels were not tested at the lower pH (10.0). Austenitic low-Ni stainless steel (204Cu) showed much better and constant corrosion performance. The other types of austenitic and duplex stainless steels showed very low or no corrosion activities; the ν corr are close to zero. The results at the lower pH 10.0 (Fig. 3b) also indicated very low corrosion activity and the ν corr values close to zero all stainless steels.

Section2.Heading: Long-term Laboratory Exposure
Section2.Para: The ER probe thicknesses were measured periodically. Figure 4a shows that all embedded carbon steel ER probes thinned rapidly and failed after 220 days of exposure. The rapid thickness change ∆d (~ 200 µm) indicated a local corrosion process which cut off (at least) one of the conductive leads of the ER probes. The stainless steel ER probes (Fig. 4b) did not show any ∆d in 1877 days of exposure.

CaptionContent.SimplePara: Thickness change (∆d) of a carbon steel and b stainless steel ER probes embedded in concrete specimens exposed to wetting-drying cycles

Section2.Heading: Marine Environment Exposure
Section2.Para: In the splash and tidal zones and in the zone below the surface, the carbon steel ER probes (Fig. 5a) began to corrode in the third year of exposure. The thickness change (∆d) occurred very rapidly, indicating local corrosion damage. No ∆d was measured deep in the water, where the oxygen level is low. A slowly increasing thickness was observed in the dry zone, which could indicate general corrosion on the protected part of the ER probe. The results for ∆d on the stainless steel ER probes (Fig. 5b) showed no corrosion activity.

CaptionContent.SimplePara: Thickness change of a carbon and b stainless steel ER probes, according to the different exposure zones. An example of partial current measurements on c carbon and d stainless steel coupled multi-electrodes, according to the different exposure zone

Section2.Para: Short measurements of the anodic and cathodic currents on the coupled multi-electrodes were performed several times per year. During individual measurements the currents stayed within the range of very small fluctuations and did not shift between anodic and cathodic sites (Figs. 5c, d).The carbon steel electrodes (Fig. 5c) in the tidal and in-water zones were anodic during the entire exposure, whereas the electrodes below the surface and in the splash zone generated cathodic currents. This could imply that the neighbouring electrodes acted as an anode/cathode pair. The corrosion currents in the dry zone were expected to be zero (no electrolyte), but—presumably due to the not completely dry conditions—a low cathodic response was measured. Figure 5d shows much lower currents on the stainless steel coupled multi-electrodes (close to zero) than on the carbon steel electrodes (Fig. 5c).

Comparisons of measurement results on ER probes and coupled multi-electrodes can be difficult: the ER probes were not connected and reflect corrosion at individual positions, whereas the coupled multi-electrodes behaved as one single rebar with separated anodic and cathodic processes on each electrode.

Section1.Heading: Conclusions
Section1.Para: From the presented investigations, the following conclusions can be drawn:

ItemContent.Para: Traditional austenitic (AISI 304 and 304L) and duplex (SAE/UNS S3 2205 and UGIGRIP 4362) stainless steel reinforcements behave significantly better in Cl− contaminated concrete environments than carbon steel.

Austenitic low-Ni stainless steel (204Cu) shows similar corrosion resistance to that of the traditional austenitic stainless steels, whereas the ferritic TOP12 stainless steel is not suitable for use in Cl− and low pH environments.
The use of ER probes is a good method for detecting corrosion initiation and for measuring general corrosion in concrete.
Coupled multi-electrodes are promising for measuring separate anodic and cathodic currents in concrete. Some interpretation issues still need to be addressed.
